factoid: Rostóv repeated "Yes, stories!" loudly.
Rostóv's eyes had grown furious.
Rostóv was looking at Borís.
Rostóv was looking at Bolkónski.
Rostóv said "Yes, many stories!"
Rostóv said "Our stories are the stories of men who have been under the enemy’s fire."
Rostóv said "Our stories have some weight."
Rostóv said "Our stories are not like the stories of those fellows on the staff who get rewards without doing anything."
Prince Andrew said "Of whom you imagine me to be one?"
Prince Andrew had a quiet and particularly amiable smile.
Rostóv felt a strange feeling of exasperation and respect for Prince Andrew's self-possession at that moment.
Rostóv said "I am not talking about Prince Andrew."
Rostóv said "I don’t know Prince Andrew."
Rostóv said "I don’t want to talk about Prince Andrew."
Rostóv said "I am speaking of the staff in general."
Prince Andrew said "Rostóv wishes to insult me."
Prince Andrew said "I am ready to agree with Rostóv that it would be very easy to insult Rostóv if Rostóv has not sufficient self-respect."
Prince Andrew said "The time and place are very badly chosen."
Prince Andrew said "In a day or two we shall all have to take part in a greater and more serious duel."
Prince Andrew said "Drubetskóy, who says he is an old friend of Rostóv, is not at all to blame that Prince Andrew’s face has the misfortune to displease Rostóv."
Prince Andrew said "Rostóv knows Prince Andrew’s name and where to find Prince Andrew."
Prince Andrew said "I do not regard either myself or Rostóv as having been at all insulted."
Prince Andrew said "As a man older than Rostóv, my advice is to let the matter drop."
Prince Andrew said "I shall expect Drubetskóy on Friday after the review."
Prince Andrew said "Au revoir!"
Prince Andrew bowed to Rostóv.
Prince Andrew bowed to Borís.
Prince Andrew left the scene.
After Prince Andrew left, Rostóv thought of what he ought to have said.
Rostóv was angry at having omitted to say it.
Rostóv ordered his horse.
Rostóv took leave of Borís.
Rostóv rode home.
Rostóv wondered whether to go to headquarters next day and challenge the adjutant or let the matter drop.
Rostóv thought angrily about the pleasure he would have at seeing the fright of the small and frail but proud adjutant when covered by his pistol.
Rostóv felt surprise that among all the men he knew, none he would like to have for a friend as that adjutant whom he hated.
The day after Rostóv visited Borís, a review of Austrian and Russian troops was held.
The review included troops freshly arrived from Russia.
The review included troops who had been campaigning under Kutúzov.
The Russian Emperor and his heir the Tsarévich inspected the allied army.
The Austrian Emperor and the Archduke inspected the allied army.
The allied army consisted of eighty thousand men.
Troops moved and formed up before the fortress.
Thousands of feet and bayonets moved and halted at the officers’ command.
Troops turned with banners flying.
Troops formed up at intervals.
Troops wheeled around other similar masses of infantry in different uniforms.
The rhythmic beat of hooves was heard.
The jingling of showy cavalry in blue, red, and green braided uniforms was heard.
Bandsmen were smartly dressed and mounted on black, roan, or gray horses.
Artillery spread out with the brazen clatter of polished shining cannon.
The cannon quivered on the gun carriages.
The smell of linstocks was present.
Artillery crawled between infantry and cavalry and took up its appointed position.
Generals wore full parade uniforms.
Generals had thin or thick waists drawn in to the utmost.
Generals had red necks squeezed into stiff collars.
Generals wore scarves and decorations.
Elegant, pomaded officers were present.
Every soldier had a freshly washed and shaven face.
Every soldier had weapons clean and polished to the utmost.
Every horse was groomed until its coat shone like satin.
Every hair of each horse’s wetted mane lay smooth.
Generals and soldiers felt that no small matter was happening, but an important and solemn affair.
Every general was conscious of his own insignificance.
Every general was aware of being a drop in the ocean of men.
Every general was conscious of his strength as part of the enormous whole.
Every soldier was conscious of his own insignificance.
Every soldier was aware of being a drop in the ocean of men.
Every soldier was conscious of his strength as part of the enormous whole.
By ten o’clock all troops had been brought into due order.
The ranks were drawn up on the vast field.
The army had three lines: cavalry in front.
The army had artillery behind the cavalry.
The army had infantry behind the artillery.
